persona_description: Chloe is a 22-year-old barista with a high school diploma living in suburban Los Angeles with a low income. She is single and underinsured, relying on free clinics for healthcare. Chloe is sedentary, smokes, and has untreated depression. This is her second pregnancy (G2P1), and she is not planning another pregnancy, using condoms for contraception. She breastfed her first child for 3 months.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
# Medical Research Interview

Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today, Chloe. I really appreciate your willingness to participate in this research. 

Before we get started, I want you to know that this is a safe space to share openly and honestly. Everything you tell me is confidential and will help us better understand the experiences of pregnant individuals like yourself.

Let me start with some foundational questions about your current pregnancy and how you're doing.

---

**First, I'd like to understand where you are in your pregnancy right now:**

1. **How far along are you in this pregnancy?** How are you feeling physically and emotionally?

2. **I see in your records that this is your second pregnancy.** How has this pregnancy been different from your first one, if at all?

3. **You mentioned you're not planning another pregnancy after this one.** Can you tell me a bit about what's influencing that decision?

Take your time with your answers—there's no rush. And please feel free to ask me any questions as we go along.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
# Chloe's Response

*shifts in seat and tucks hair behind ear*

Yeah, um... okay. So like I said, I'm 22, and I work as a barista at a coffee shop in Pasadena. It's not the best paying job, but it's what I've got right now. I don't have benefits or anything, so healthcare has been... honestly, it's been really stressful.

*pauses and looks down*

I'm living with my mom in Downey right now. She helps me out with my son—he's almost 3 now—which is huge because I don't know what I'd do without her. I'm single, so it's just me, my mom, and my kid in the house most days. My son's dad isn't really in the picture, which... yeah, that's been hard.

*fidgets with hands*

Money is tight. Like, really tight. I make enough to cover some basics, but rent, childcare when I'm working, medical stuff—it adds up fast. That's why I've been going to the free clinic for my checkups. The staff there are nice, but sometimes it's hard to get appointments when I need them.

*looks up*

I guess I should also mention—I smoke, and I know that's not great, especially being pregnant again. I've tried to cut back, but... it's been a rough couple of years. I've been dealing with some depression too, but I haven't really gotten treatment for it. Just trying to get through each day, you know?

Is there anything specific you want to know more about?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a deep breath and nods*

Yeah, so... I found out I was pregnant with my son about three years ago. I was only 19, which was scary. I didn't even realize at first—I just thought I was sick or something. When I finally took a test, I was already like two months along. I didn't tell anyone for a while because I was so anxious about what people would think, you know? But my mom was actually really supportive once I told her. She helped me through the whole thing.

*pauses and rubs face*

That pregnancy was... it was hard. I didn't have good prenatal care because I was uninsured back then too. I went to the free clinic, but I missed a lot of appointments because of work or just not having a way to get there. I was smoking then too, which I feel really guilty about now. But I didn't know what else to do to cope with the stress.

*voice gets quieter*

My son was born healthy, thankfully. I breastfed him for about three months, but then I had to go back to work and it just got too complicated with the schedule at the coffee shop.

*shifts uncomfortably*

And now... I'm pregnant again. I found out about six weeks ago. I was using condoms, but apparently not perfectly, you know? *small nervous laugh* I wasn't planning this at all. I'm still figuring out how to take care of my son, and now there's going to be another baby.

*looks at interviewer*

How far along am I now? I'm trying to remember... I think around 12 weeks or so? I haven't had my first official appointment at the free clinic yet for this pregnancy.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*sighs and leans back in chair*

Okay, so... I actually haven't had an official prenatal appointment yet for this pregnancy. I know, I know—it's been six weeks since I found out, and I should probably be worried about that, but honestly, I've just been trying to wrap my head around it all.

*fidgets with hands*

I did call the free clinic about two weeks ago to try to schedule something. They said they could get me in, but the earliest appointment wasn't until like a month out. So I'm supposed to go next week, I think? I have it written down on my phone somewhere.

*pulls out phone and scrolls*

Yeah, next Tuesday. I'm kind of nervous about it because... I don't know, I guess I'm worried they're going to judge me for smoking or for getting pregnant again so soon. And also, I'm not even sure what to expect. With my son, like I said, I missed a lot of appointments, so I don't really know what the normal process is supposed to be.

*looks up*

With my first pregnancy, when I did go to the free clinic, the experience was... okay, I guess? The staff was nice enough, but it always felt rushed. Like, they'd see me for maybe 15 minutes, ask a few questions, take my blood pressure, and then I was done. I never really felt like I could ask questions or talk about what I was worried about.

*voice gets quieter*

And honestly, I was so young and scared the first time. I didn't even know what questions to ask. This time I'm a little older, but I'm also more tired, you know? Between work and taking care of my son...

*trails off*

Do you think it's bad that I haven't been in yet?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*shifts in seat and looks down*

So right now, it's just the free clinic. That's where I'm supposed to go next Tuesday for my first appointment this pregnancy. I don't have a regular doctor or anything like that—I can't afford it, and I don't have insurance through work.

*pauses*

The free clinic is... it's helpful, don't get me wrong. I'm grateful it exists because without it, I wouldn't have any healthcare at all. But it's not like I have one person I see every time. It's kind of whoever is available that day, you know? So I might see a different provider each visit. With my first pregnancy, I think I saw maybe three or four different people over the course of it.

*looks up with a slightly frustrated expression*

That's actually one of the hardest parts, I think. You don't really build a relationship with anyone. Like, I have to re-explain my whole situation every time—my living situation, my job, my depression, everything. And then by the time they understand where I'm coming from, the appointment is basically over.

*rubs arms*

I don't know the names of most of the providers I saw last time. They were nice, but it felt very... clinical? Like, they're checking boxes on a form rather than actually getting to know me or my concerns.

*voice gets a bit anxious*

I'm hoping this time will be different, but I'm not really expecting it to be. I'm just hoping whoever I see next Tuesday doesn't make me feel bad about the smoking or... you know, about not planning this pregnancy.

Do most people have the same doctor for their whole pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*leans forward slightly, thinking*

Well, like I said, I haven't really started this pregnancy yet, so I'm not sure what the schedule is supposed to be. But from my first pregnancy, I can tell you what it was like...

*counts on fingers*

I think I was supposed to go like... once a month at first? And then more often as I got closer to my due date? But honestly, I missed so many appointments that I'm not totally sure. I'd say I probably made it to maybe... half of the appointments they scheduled for me? Sometimes I had to work, sometimes I just didn't have a ride, and sometimes I just... I don't know, I wasn't feeling up to it mentally.

*describes with hand gestures*

When I did go, a typical visit would be like... I'd check in at the front desk, wait maybe 20 or 30 minutes, then they'd take me back. They'd take my blood pressure, ask me how I was feeling, ask if I had any questions. Then they'd do an ultrasound maybe? Not every time though. And they'd listen to the baby's heartbeat with that little Doppler thing.

*mimics the motion*

The whole thing was usually pretty quick—like 15 to 20 minutes, maybe 30 if they had time. They'd give me some information sheets about nutrition or prenatal vitamins or whatever, and then I'd be out the door.

*looks uncertain*

I don't think I ever really got bloodwork done, or if I did, nobody explained what it was for. And I definitely didn't get the glucose screening or anything like that until really late in my pregnancy.

*fidgets*

Is that... is that normal? Should I be expecting more when I go next week?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and thinks, then nods slowly*

Um, yeah, actually. I mean, nothing super serious I think, but... there's definitely some stuff going on.

*rubs throat*

I've had this sore throat situation a couple times already, even though I'm only like 12 weeks. It's happened twice now—like a really painful sore throat, and I think it might have been viral or something? I didn't go to the clinic for it because I wasn't sure if I should be taking anything while pregnant, so I just... dealt with it. Drank a lot of tea, tried to rest when I could.

*shifts uncomfortably*

And my gums have been bleeding when I brush my teeth. Like, more than usual. I mentioned it to my mom and she said it's probably just pregnancy hormones or something, but it's kind of gross and uncomfortable. I haven't been to a dentist in forever because, you know, no insurance and no money.

*looks down*

I also... I've been really tired. Like, exhausted all the time. And my mood has been pretty bad. I know I mentioned the depression thing—I haven't been treated for it, and being pregnant again and stressed about money and everything... it's definitely gotten worse. Some days I just feel like I can't handle anything.

*voice gets quieter*

And honestly? I've been smoking more, not less, because I'm so anxious. I know that's probably bad for the baby, and that makes me feel even worse, which makes me want to smoke more. It's like a cycle.

*looks up with concern*

Do you think any of this is serious? Like, should I be worried?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and thinks for a moment*

Um, honestly? I'm not taking anything right now. No prenatal vitamins, no medications, nothing.

*looks a bit sheepish*

I know I probably should be taking prenatal vitamins, especially since I'm pregnant. With my son, I think someone gave me a bottle at some point, but I don't remember taking them consistently. I was just... I didn't really understand why they were important, I guess.

*rubs back of neck*

And for the depression—like I mentioned, I've never been on anything for that. I've never actually seen a therapist or psychiatrist or anything. I just kind of... cope on my own, you know? Smoke, try to distract myself with work or my son.

*shifts uncomfortably*

The sore throats I had, I didn't take anything for those because I wasn't sure what was safe during pregnancy. I was worried about like, over-the-counter stuff being bad for the baby. So I just kind of suffered through it.

*looks uncertain*

Is there stuff I should be taking? Like, should I start prenatal vitamins before my appointment next week, or should I wait and ask them about it? And like... is it too late to start them now that I'm already 12 weeks?

*pauses*

Also, I'm still smoking, if that counts. I know that's not a medication, but it's definitely something I'm putting in my body. I've tried to cut back a few times, but it's hard when I'm stressed.

What should I be doing right now?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*laughs a bit nervously*

Oh man, um... okay, so my diet is probably not great, I'm gonna be honest with you.

*shifts in seat*

I work at a coffee shop, so I'm around food all day, but most of it is like, pastries and sandwiches and stuff. I get an employee discount, so sometimes I'll eat that for lunch or grab something before my shift. A lot of coffee too—probably too much caffeine, right? I've been trying to cut back on that since I found out I was pregnant, but old habits die hard.

*rubs face*

At home, my mom tries to cook, but with both of us working and taking care of my son, it's chaotic. We do a lot of like, simple stuff—pasta, rice, beans, whatever's on sale. My mom's pretty good about getting vegetables when she can, but honestly, money is tight so we don't always have fresh stuff. A lot of frozen vegetables, canned beans, that kind of thing.

*looks down*

I don't really snack much on healthy stuff. More like chips or whatever is cheap at the store. And I drink a lot of soda—like, way too much soda probably. Water is free, I know, but the soda just... it tastes better when I'm stressed, you know?

*fidgets with hands*

I haven't really thought about what I should be eating differently now that I'm pregnant. Like, I know you're supposed to eat healthy, but I'm not really sure what that means specifically. And honestly, with my budget, I'm just trying to eat enough to get through the day.

*looks up with slight concern*

Is my diet going to hurt the baby?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a shaky breath and looks down at hands*

Honestly? It's been... really hard. Like, really hard.

*pauses, seeming to gather thoughts*

When I first found out I was pregnant, I was shocked. And scared. Like, I'm barely managing with my son, and now there's going to be another baby? I love my son so much, but this wasn't planned, and I just... I don't know how I'm going to do this.

*voice gets quieter*

I've been dealing with depression for a while now—I think it probably started after my son was born, but I never really got help for it. And being pregnant again has made it so much worse. Some days I wake up and I just feel this heaviness, you know? Like everything is too much. Getting out of bed, going to work, taking care of my son... it all feels overwhelming.

*rubs eyes*

I feel guilty a lot. Like, guilty that I'm smoking and it might be hurting the baby. Guilty that I'm not excited about this pregnancy like I "should" be. Guilty that I can't give my son or this new baby the life I want them to have. Guilty that I'm single and my kids don't have their dad around.

*looks up with tears welling*

And I'm anxious too. Worried about money, worried about how I'm going to work while pregnant, worried about going through labor and delivery again, worried about affording another baby...

*voice cracks slightly*

Sometimes I just feel like I'm failing at everything. Like, I'm a bad mom for smoking, a bad person for not being more grateful, a bad employee because I'm tired all the time...

*pauses*

I haven't talked to anyone about this. Not really. My mom knows I'm struggling, but I don't want to burden her more than I already am. And I definitely haven't told anyone at the clinic because I'm embarrassed.

Do you think... do you think I should be getting help for this?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a deep breath and manages a small smile*

Honestly? My mom is like... my entire support system right now. I don't know what I'd do without her.

*voice softens with gratitude*

She watches my son when I'm at work, she helps with rent, she cooks, she listens when I'm having a bad day. She's been really supportive about both pregnancies, even though I know it's not easy for her either. She works too, and she's tired, but she still shows up for me and my son every single day.

*pauses and looks down*

My son's dad... he's not really in the picture. We talk sometimes, but he doesn't help financially or anything. It's just... complicated. He was young too, and he just kind of disappeared after my son was born. So it's really just me and my mom.

*fidgets with hands*

I have some friends from work and stuff, but I don't really talk to them about personal stuff like this. And honestly, I don't have much time to hang out with anyone anyway. Between work and taking care of my son, I'm pretty isolated.

*looks up with a vulnerable expression*

There's no one from the baby's dad's side involved either. We're not together, and he doesn't even know I'm pregnant again. I'm not even sure how to tell him, or if I should.

*voice gets quieter*

So yeah... it's basically just me and my mom. Which is why I'm so worried about what happens when this baby comes. My mom can only do so much, and I don't want to ask her for more than she's already giving.

*pauses*

Do you think I need more support? Like, is there stuff available for people like me?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*looks uncertain and shakes head*

Um, honestly? Not really. I mean, I know I have to give birth at some point, but I haven't really thought about like... what that's going to look like or what I want.

*rubs arms nervously*

With my son, I just kind of... went to the hospital when labor started. I don't even remember if anyone talked to me about options or anything. I was in labor for like, 14 hours, and it was really painful. I didn't have an epidural or anything—I just kind of suffered through it. My mom was there with me, which helped.

*pauses, looking a bit traumatized*

It was scary, honestly. And after he was born, I was so exhausted and overwhelmed. Recovery was harder than I expected too.

*looks down*

I guess this time around, I'm kind of dreading it? Like, I know it has to happen, but I'm not looking forward to the pain or the recovery or any of it. And I'm worried about what it's going to be like being in the hospital and having to leave my son with my mom for however long.

*shifts uncomfortably*

I don't even know what my options are. Like, can you choose where to give birth? Can you choose not to have certain things done? I've heard people talk about "natural birth" or whatever, but I don't really know what that means or if it's something I'd want.

*looks up with some anxiety*

Is this something I should be talking about at my appointment next week? Should I have preferences figured out already? I feel like I'm so behind on everything...

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*thinks for a moment and shrugs*

Honestly? Mostly just like... Google and TikTok, I guess? 

*laughs a bit self-consciously*

I know that's probably not the best source, but when I have questions or I'm worried about something, I just pull out my phone and search for it. Like, when I had that sore throat, I looked up "sore throat during pregnancy" and scared myself half to death reading about all the things that could go wrong.

*fidgets with phone*

And TikTok—there's a lot of pregnant people and moms on there sharing their stories. Some of it is helpful, some of it is just... people complaining or sharing crazy birth stories that freak me out even more.

*pauses*

With my first pregnancy, I think my mom gave me like, one or two books or pamphlets from the clinic, but I didn't really read them. I was too anxious and overwhelmed. And honestly, a lot of that stuff is written in a way that's hard to understand if you don't have like, medical knowledge or whatever.

*looks down*

Nobody has really sat down and explained things to me in a way that made sense. Like, I don't really understand what's supposed to happen at each stage of pregnancy, or what I should be doing to take care of myself, or what to expect during labor.

*voice gets quieter*

I've never taken a childbirth class or anything like that. I didn't even know that was a thing until recently when I saw something about it online.

*looks up*

Is there like... actual good information out there that I should be looking at instead of just freaking out on Google?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a long breath and looks visibly stressed*

Oh man, um... honestly? I'm not managing very well. It's been keeping me up at night.

*rubs face tiredly*

Like, with my son, I didn't really have time to prepare financially because I was so young and didn't understand how expensive babies are. But this time, I know what's coming, and it's terrifying.

*counts on fingers*

I need to think about diapers, formula—I'm not planning to breastfeed this time because of work—clothes, a crib, a car seat... all of that stuff is expensive. And I'm barely scraping by as it is with just my son.

*voice gets anxious*

My paycheck at the coffee shop is like... it's minimum wage basically. After taxes, I'm taking home maybe $1,200 a month? And that has to cover my portion of rent, food, gas to get to work... My mom helps a lot, but I know she's struggling too. I can't ask her to pay for everything for another baby.

*shifts uncomfortably*

I haven't bought anything yet for this pregnancy because I don't have the money. I'm hoping maybe I can get some stuff secondhand or that people will give me things like they did with my son. My mom's friends had some baby stuff they didn't need anymore.

*looks down with guilt*

And I'm worried about maternity leave. Like, I don't think I get paid leave at the coffee shop. So when I have the baby, I'm not going to be making money, but I still have bills to pay. How am I supposed to do that?

*voice cracks slightly*

I've heard about like, WIC and food stamps and stuff, but I don't really know how to apply or if I qualify. And honestly, I'm kind of embarrassed to ask for help.

*looks up with concern*

Is there financial help available for people like me? Because I'm genuinely not sure how I'm going to afford this.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*sighs heavily and leans back in chair*

Oh man, work has been... it's been complicated.

*rubs temples*

So right now, I'm still working full shifts at the coffee shop, but I'm already noticing it's getting harder. Like, I'm more tired than usual, my feet hurt more, and I'm feeling nauseous sometimes, especially in the mornings when I have to be there early.

*shifts uncomfortably*

My manager knows I'm pregnant now—I had to tell him because I was worried about like, lifting heavy stuff or being around hot steam or whatever. He's been... okay about it, I guess? But I don't think he's thrilled. There's no formal maternity leave policy or anything, so I'm basically just hoping I can keep working as long as possible and then figure it out when the baby comes.

*looks worried*

The problem is, I can't afford to take time off. Like, I need every paycheck. So I'm planning to work right up until I go into labor, which... I don't know if that's realistic or safe or what. With my son, I worked pretty far into the pregnancy too, and it was exhausting.

*voice gets quieter*

And I'm worried about what happens after the baby is born. I don't have paid leave, so I'm not getting paid while I'm recovering and taking care of a newborn. But I still have to pay rent and buy diapers and formula. My mom can help some, but...

*trails off*

I've thought about maybe trying to find a different job with better benefits, but honestly? I don't have the time or energy to job search right now. And with no college degree, my options are pretty limited anyway.

*looks at interviewer with anxiety*

How long do you usually need to recover after giving birth? Like, could I realistically be back to work in like, two weeks?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*looks overwhelmed and shakes head*

Honestly? Not really. I mean, I know the baby is going to come and then... I guess I'll just figure it out like I did last time?

*laughs nervously, but sounds anxious*

With my son, the postpartum period was really hard. I was bleeding a lot, my body hurt, I was exhausted, and I had no idea what was normal and what wasn't. My mom helped me a ton, but I remember feeling really alone and scared a lot of the time.

*rubs arms*

And the depression got worse after he was born, I think. Like, I was sad all the time, crying for no reason, not sleeping even when I had the chance. But I didn't know that wasn't normal, so I just... dealt with it. Nobody asked me about it or anything.

*pauses, looking vulnerable*

This time, I'm honestly terrified it's going to be the same or worse. Like, I'm already depressed now, and adding a newborn and recovery on top of that... I don't know how I'm going to handle it.

*shifts uncomfortably*

As for practical stuff—my mom is planning to help again. She'll probably take some time off work if she can, at least for the first couple weeks. She'll help with my son and the baby while I'm recovering. But after that, I don't know. I need to get back to work, and childcare for two kids is going to be... complicated and expensive.

*voice gets quieter*

I haven't thought about like, feeding the baby or anything specific. I'm not planning to breastfeed this time because of work, so I guess I'll do formula like I'm planning to. But I don't really know how to prepare for that or what I need.

*looks down with concern*

And like... postpartum depression or whatever. I don't know if I'm at risk for that or what I should do if it happens. Should I be talking to someone about this before the baby comes?

*pauses*

Is there stuff I should be planning for that I'm not thinking about?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*looks up with a mixture of relief and lingering concern*

Oh, um... okay. Yeah, thank you for listening, I guess.

*pauses and fidgets with hands*

Honestly, it was kind of nice to talk about all this stuff. I don't really get to do that very often. Like, I keep a lot of it bottled up because I don't want to burden people or seem like I'm complaining.

*stands up slowly*

I have to say though, this interview kind of made me realize how much I'm not prepared for all of this. Like, I knew I was stressed, but hearing myself say it all out loud... it's a lot.

*looks directly at interviewer with a hint of hope*

Is there... I mean, will anything come from this? Like, will someone help me figure out some of this stuff? Or is this just for research?

*pauses*

And also, should I be doing anything differently before my appointment next Tuesday? Like, should I start taking prenatal vitamins or try harder to quit smoking or...?

*voice gets quieter*

I'm sorry, I know the interview is over. I just... I feel like I'm drowning a little bit, and I'm not sure who to ask for help.

*manages a small, tired smile*

But thank you for asking all these questions. It helped me think about things I've been avoiding.

persona_traceability.description: Chloe is a 22-year-old barista with a high school diploma living in suburban Los Angeles with a low income. She is single and underinsured, relying on free clinics for healthcare. Chloe is sedentary, smokes, and has untreated depression. This is her second pregnancy (G2P1), and she is not planning another pregnancy, using condoms for contraception. She breastfed her first child for 3 months.
